property.name: mediadisplayblurb
property.value: Map showing the extent of the Mughal Empire

note.text: In the early 16th century CE, the Mughal dynasty took control of northern India, including the area that is now Pakistan. The founder of the dynasty, Babur, was descended from Tamerlane and Genghis Khan. Urdu, which was spoken by the Mughal elite, began to be used as a common language, or lingua franca, among the various groups at this time. The Mughals were the last Muslim dynasty to rule this area.
British expansion throughout South Asia eventually brought the Mughal Empire to an end in the 1850s.
